number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has a beautiful underwater world, with very unique creatures inhabiting the depths. There are so many interesting areas to explore, and you can tell the devs put a lot of work into the details. You are on an alien planet covered in water. You crash-landed here, with no idea what type of world it is. You must learn about its inhabitants, and occaisionally eat them, even if they are cute. An awesome survival aspect, that doesn't include the over-used zombie infestation. Instead, you have marine animals, that are both aggressive and friendly. The game can be peaceful, or scary, depending on what you are doing. There are lots of useful items to craft, resources to gather, and a few cool vehicles to make exploring even easier. One of them includes the giant Cyclops submarine. You can practically live in it. The devlopers are very open with what they are working on, and there are large updates often. There is an in-game feedback and bug report menu which allows you to submit complaints or feedback in real-time. The game is really unique and fun, and I'm looking forward to every update!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								I will just make this short and sweet. I would not normally touch survival games with a 10 foot pole, since I don`t get them. They are feel like busy work to me and more about messing up other players than playing a game. I was interested in this game ever since it was announced, so I kept and eye on it. I finally got it in the freedom bundle and even though I have played just a little, I can say for sure this is one of the best Survival games out there (I have played a few using my friends accounts, did not like any of them). The fact that it does not have Multiplayer is a huge plus for me. The game is not punishing too much, look incredible and has tons of stuff to do. It is also helping with my hydrophobia which is another plus!It is almost sad that a crap like NMS gets all the publicity and this game goes half noticed, but I guess it must be doing ok since the Devs are working on it still. I hope it gets finished and be one the very examples of survival games that actually gets released. The only negative point I saw was the awkward swimming animations for the larger creatures, I hope it gets fixed.PS: I see many are asking for MP, if they ever put it in they SHOULD put an option to opt out. I do not want to deal with other a-holes tying to mess up my game. I like it just the way it is now.

content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								I will just make this short and sweet. I would not normally touch survival games with a 10 foot pole, since I don`t get them. They are feel like busy work to me and more about messing up other players than playing a game. I was interested in this game ever since it was announced, so I kept and eye on it. I finally got it in the freedom bundle and even though I have played just a little, I can say for sure this is one of the best Survival games out there (I have played a few using my friends accounts, did not like any of them). The fact that it does not have Multiplayer is a huge plus for me. The game is not punishing too much, look incredible and has tons of stuff to do. It is also helping with my hydrophobia which is another plus!It is almost sad that a crap like NMS gets all the publicity and this game goes half noticed, but I guess it must be doing ok since the Devs are working on it still. I hope it gets finished and be one the very examples of survival games that actually gets released. The only negative point I saw was the awkward swimming animations for the larger creatures, I hope it gets fixed.PS: I see many are asking for MP, if they ever put it in they SHOULD put an option to opt out. I do not want to deal with other a-holes tying to mess up my game. I like it just the way it is now.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								The depths of the ocean pose more dangers and difficulties in reaching than does outer space.  No other environment can inspire the levels of fear & dread that the ocean can, where the vast distances and minimal visibility mean that colossal beasts can end up right next to you before you can even see them, and everything down there wants to eat you.It can also be a wonderous place, filled with exotic creatures that we could never have imagined before we actually saw them.  Corals, anemones, plants and animals of all kinds can inspire awe & wonder on par with the terror of unknown that only the ocean can deliver.Subnautica delivers all of these things in concentrated doses, carefully structured to instill the player with both the horror and wonder of the oceans.  Then they up the ante by making it an alien world, so you can't even use real-life examples as a guide (well, actually you can - more on that later).  Using an equally liberal hand with both absolute darkness and gratuitous bioluminescence, the depths at night are both terrifying and beautiful.  Everything seems to glow, and the few things that don't you wish did glow, because the darkness is terrifying.Let me expand on that: Very few games out there can deliver any real sense of fear beyond cheap "jump scares."  While having a giant moster leap out and thrash your submarine can indeed deliver the same thing, the real horror factor is the fear of the unknown.  It's in not knowing what could possibly be at the bottom of that hole in the seafloor, or hearing the dreadful baying of a giant beast nearby but not knowing where it came from - and in a fully 3D environment, that could mean above or below you, as well.  The game primes you for fear before delivering the attack, constantly teasing your sense of curiosity to lure you into greater depths and greater dangers.  The point being, however, that even in areas free of hostile life the game still keeps you nervous and on edge with it's mind-twisting audio and constant paranoia about what could be living just beyond the edge of your feeble flashlight beam.  And no matter how far down you go, there's always a bigger fish and always a deeper, darker cave.  I haven't this much fun just aimlessly wandering around a map & exploring since Skyrim came out.  But wait, there's more!  The devs wisely gave the player (currently) four different difficulty settings to pick from, going all the way from hardcore survival mode to freeform, danger-free exploration.  This is good because it means both your five year old nephew and your crazy ex-Navy SEAL uncle can both enjoy this game.  It also lets you build underwater bases with a wide variety of rooms, furniture, and functionality.  This gives a good outlet for the player's creative side, as you can build those bases as small or large as you like.  Want a big headquarters with all the comforts of home?  You can do that.  Want to put a network of lone rest & resupply tubes scattered all over the map?  You can do that too.  Whatever works best for you - there is no "one best way" towards base design, or even gameplay, and honestly that's a rare thing in survival games.Of course the game isn't perfect.  It is, after all, Early Access and that's something that I've become rather loathe to even look at after so much garbage flooding Steam over the past few years.  I made sure to watch plenty of LetsPlay videos, read guides, wikis and forums before finally caving in and getting this game.  While I've been pleasantly surprised, it's still not without it's flaws - though it's a short list, thankfully.Now I'm not going to complain about the "story" being incomplete because it is Early Access so some missing pieces are to be expected.  However, all the pieces currently in game fit together.  There aren't too many "placeholders" reminding us that it's still under construction.  There's a lot of things that need tweaking, but nothing that I'd really consider broken.First, and this is likely due to trying to keep it XBOX compatible, the whole thing is done in Unity (not my favorite game engine, and I'll explain why thus).  While Unity is very user-friendly for game developers, and great at making things look pretty, in the long run it tends to suffer from terrible optimization & memory bloat - and this game is no exception.  Even one decently sized underwater base will cause a noticable slowdown, and trying to build multiple bases will further compound this issue until the entire game becomes completely unplayable.Second, and again I blame XBOX, there is zero modding support and it doesn't look like there ever will be.  I find that very disappointing, because modding is the #1 decider in long-term viability & replay value.  Maybe I've just been spoiled by years of Bethesda games, but I find that not including mod support in 2016 to be simply incomprehensible.Third, there is only one map and every game uses it.  This means that, again, long-term replay value is going to take a hit.  When discovery & exploraion is the meat of your game, you're going to want to implement ways to keep that idea fresh without having to personally go in and program new stuff every week.  Some kind of randomization via seed numbers would be ideal, so that people can replay the same map over if they want to (just write down your seed number and use it again), but those who want a new experience every time could pick a random number and see what happens.Forth, and this is the most minor quibble: Most of the technology makes no damn sense.  It's Star Trek in some places, stone-age in others.  I understand that sometimes suspension of disbelief must take a back seat to gameplay balance, but this is more like gameplay jacking realism's car and kicking them out the passenger door at gunpoint.  With everything else being so realistically detailed, this can be very immersion breaking at times.Despite these minor issues, I do feel that I've already got my money's worth out of Subnautica.  It's been a rare treat to find a game that can combine an exploration theme, a horror theme, and a building theme together and have all of it's elements actually work right together.  I can only imagine it getting even more interesting as time goes on.

Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								An absolutely beautiful and intensely immersive game. However, I am an extravert and I like player interaction, and this is something I sorely miss when playing this game. Unless Subnautica evolves into a multiplayer coop with an expanded map, I am afraid I won’t clock many hours on this. Future updates will show, keep’em coming, Devs!Pros: Creative aspectThe beauty and mystery of the oceanPlenty to exploreA gem for the imaginative types who like to explore and create in solitudeHealthy balance between the feelings of fear and safety, strategic thinking and plain wild creativityImprovements needed:Added multi-player to avoid the feeling of lonely boredomMap expansion, new areas to exploreIncreased and more varied creature interactionHumourDolphins, where are the alien dolphins?In conclusion, I would recommend buying this game if you don’t mind a few hours of lonely play.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played this game for an hour and then refunded. I then went on to watch some videos of other people playing and saw all the content I was missing and how much work the devs were putting into the future of this game and immediately re-purchased the game. This game is deceptive at first, it's pretty but seems to be sameish after an hour of fooling around until you realize how to unlock the more advanced gear and start exploring further and deeper and properly building up a beautiful base you actually want to live in. This game gets top marks for creativity, visuals, sounds, and replayability. There is quite a bit of placeholder art at the moment which was a disappointment to me but the art that is in place is beautiful. I look forward to playing more of this game (currently played around 6 hours across 2 saves) and discovering what the devs have hidden away in the depths. If you like movies like The Martian and Interstellar I cannot recommend this game enough because it will let you play out your stranded fantasies on an ocean-only alien planet.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you love survival and being released into the unknown then you will love this game. I've been a minecraft fan forever and it's nice to experience a different approach in this futurist oceanish survival world. Granted, its early access but the bugs are very minimal with minor larger fish colliding but that's rare from what I see. I'm like other Vive VR owners and hate BS cr@pware demos here but this is a nice find for a small $10 with sale.My specs:i7 6700 3.4ghzSSD OS (64bit) 1T sataGeforce GTX 970 4G16G RAM DDR3Graphics @ max (local PC) = 9 out 10Graphics @ max (Vive VR) = 5 out 10 (video studders and need to run @ lower settings)Gameplay (PC mode) = 10 (Game modes are like Minecraft. You can play survival, hardcore, creative etc.) Gameplay (Vive VR) = 7 out of 10 (the vive controllers are not used but you can use gamepad or mouse/keyboard)Cost = $10 @ 50% off (well worth it!)Story line = 8 out of 10 (You really feel like you're stranded and trying to survive. Keep in mind I have not finished it so I may bump this up)Crafting aspect = 8 out of 10 (not bad but I've been spoiled with other games. Has great potiental if it goes multiplayer)Game crashing = I have yet to see it crash in 4 hours of gameplay....Bugs (Vive VR) = go graphic low setting to resolve graphic tears. High settings will glitch like crazy. Larger fish will collide and flip around. etc. As for other bugs, I have yet to see more.Sound Quality = 10 out of 10 (wow, the sound...ummmm wow!). Give that sound editor a raise!All in all, I will say this is a game to buy for folks that love playing a survival solo open world game. You really have to think and manage your inventory when you first start. The devs are doing a super job and bringing the experience to a personal level when it comes to at your own pace.Hope this helps others!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you're looking to wander around a giant area, pick up resources, and craft them into things that let you wander more and pick up different resources, this is a very solid game. I'm not a huge fan of the genre, but Subnautica is fun, fair, and challenging. The twist of it taking place underwater adds a lot of depth (hurr).Gameplay is exactly what you'd expect, as written above. None of the resources you can find or crafts you can make are too shocking. Often, survival games make eating/drinking too easy or too difficult. If it's overly easy, you just load up on supplies and eat/drink whenever, which adds nothing but time-wasting clicking. If it's too difficult, you spend most of your time making sure you're not dead, which isn't particularly fun compared to exploring. Subnautica is well-balanced in this regard.I also enjoy the fact that there is something of a story with directions on what to accomplish that you can follow or ignore at your leisure. The occasional radio transmissions you receive and coordinates you can visit kept me playing this a lot longer than I would have if it were more sandbox-y like Minecraft. I didn't encounter many bugs in my 7 hours playing through this Early-Access release. Some missing models/textures for uncommon items, but that's about it. It's a full game as it stands now; purchase with confidence.

content:
Posted: April 20
Early Access Review
								Subnautica is another one of those survival crafting games, however it does many things to stand out from the others.Subnautica provides minimal hand-holding throughout the entire game, in order to actually survive you have to figure out several things by yourself by using your brain and a little creativity. Just like actually surviving! Subnautica also encourages exploration by bombarding the player with varied and diverse biomes, as well as multiple creatures that are both hostile and friendly. The only fault I have with the game is its optimization, in some areas my computer tends to freeze up while the world decides to load in every little thing.You might look at Subnautica and think it to be just more library fodder, but it is a very good game. At this current moment, I have about seven hours in the game from two days of playing, and I still have so much left to do. With an abundance of content and promise of more to come with constant developer updates, this game is truly a great example of what Early Access should be.

If you want a chilled evening rather than a Black Ops 3 / CS manic run around (my normal fare) then take the time to explore this very well supported and much loved game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								I played this game for an hour and then refunded. I then went on to watch some videos of other people playing and saw all the content I was missing and how much work the devs were putting into the future of this game and immediately re-purchased the game. This game is deceptive at first, it's pretty but seems to be sameish after an hour of fooling around until you realize how to unlock the more advanced gear and start exploring further and deeper and properly building up a beautiful base you actually want to live in. This game gets top marks for creativity, visuals, sounds, and replayability. There is quite a bit of placeholder art at the moment which was a disappointment to me but the art that is in place is beautiful. I look forward to playing more of this game (currently played around 6 hours across 2 saves) and discovering what the devs have hidden away in the depths. If you like movies like The Martian and Interstellar I cannot recommend this game enough because it will let you play out your stranded fantasies on an ocean-only alien planet.

content:
Posted: January 22
Early Access Review
								* GAME CRASHES AFTER 15-20 HOURS AS OF 1/22/2017 FOR EVERYONE*I generally hate writing in caps but in this situation, I believe it to be warranted. Outside of the MAJOR issue which I listed above, this game is utterly fantastic. It is beautiful in almost every way. The game feels balanced. The artwork is fantastic. I feel the perfect balance of serenity and fear. Towards the end of my last save, I made it to this area called the "Grand Reef". I won't give anything away but It was daunting. It was stunningly beautiful but filled with danger. I was equal parts excited to explore and ready to get the f' out of there. I could feel my stomach sink as I reached about 500m in the Cyclops. Very few games have made me feel this way without VR. I think the game could add a ton of new content which the Devs have... but until they fix the game crashes it's not worth it. Other commenters have already explained that there are work arounds but those are temporary at best. I work as a System's Administrator and the last thing I want to do is hack away at a fix. I'm not upset or frustrated because this game is in Alpha but it does stop me from recommending this game. I've had steam now for over 6 years and have never written a review before. I love this game so much and I hope the devs fix the crashes. It's been known for months now and it's time for them to set some priorities. No more content should be added until they fix the crashes. Once they do, I'll not only change my review but I'll buy a few copies for my friends. The game is fantastic and it deserves to shine.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the most thrilling games I've ever played, not just within the exploration/survival genre, very recommended especially for you deep sea fans. I suggest you go into this game blind, no "beginner guides" or anything, and just explore. And continuously♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants. On a more serious note, as an early access title it surely rises suspicion, I too have felt screwed over by paying for an early access game (cough DayZ cough). However with Subnautica, the devs don't promise diamond mountains, keep realistic goals, and are actively discussing development in the community. Some dissatisfaction comes up about the world not being procedurally generated, but I much more prefer the developer's reasoning to make it handcrafted yet special as to avoid random areas that don't quite work together (I know what we're all thinking...I don't have to mention it).The game itself is very immersive, lots of neat flora and fauna to discover, about half of which wants to kill you because you are the intruder in their creepy deep sea fishy business. Some minor bugs are present, such as clipping rendering when exploring in one of the small vehicles, which the devs have addressed. Even if you're still skeptical, see it this way: if development suddenly drops like it tends to, you still get a great chunk of gameplay for the price. rig specs: Intel i5-4690kNvidia GTX 107016gb RAM

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								As someone who enjoys the survival-builder type of games, Subnautica has been an amazing experience. The game presents a very unique environment: It is underwater, which can get very alien and also takes place in a fictional environment.The animals and flora seem well-thought and not random, evident by the in-game encyclopedia that explains evolutionary or functional insight into the creatures.In addition to that, the game doesn't give you the easy way out: You don't just find a strong weapon and shoot things. You find alternative tools (such as blasting enemies away) and have to make use of the raw materials to craft such tools and more.While you face vibrant colors and a breathtaking setting, the game is also very tense and bleak: You are stranded, alone and you need to survive.I'm only <9 hours into the game and I've already had a lot of fun and I realize I haven't really seen anything yet.Obviously the game is in Early Access at the moment and has a lot to improve but the developers ask for your feedback and seem to be pretty into it. I'm pretty sure I'll get my money's worth even at this stage of the game, but I also have trusted the developers.I advise everyone interested to buy the game to help its development. I guarantee you, if you like the concept you see in the pictures, you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: April 20
Early Access Review
								This review is written for the EA version. I will happily take a look at the game again after the final release and change my mind if needed. Also I just played this game without watching any "Let's Plays" or "tutorials" before. I was looking forward to give it a try without any spoilers and this is just my impression from the first hours - which couldn't motivate me enough to continue playing this game. Pro:- Nice graphics. Espescially the starting area, the change of light during the day, the waves. Just beautiful.- Interesting underwater setting. Being limited in your O2 supply is not new, but the mechanics are well made in this game. - Good design for the buildings and equipment - at least if you like the style of Apple products. This also leads to a contra point... - Great sound that adds A LOT to the atmopshere, especially from the creatures. <3Contra: - It's way too easy to simply survive for a "Survival game"*- No feeling of (meaningful) progress, which is probably the most negative point for me- bugs that will make you loose your progress of the first hours* if you don't use google first- unbalanced / unrealistic game mechanics that allow you to create a huge underwater base out of scrap metal in the begining (that would require crazy high tech in real)  - but you have nearly nothing to place inside your base. And you can't even craft a simple harpoon...which would be WAY more important at this point than a fancy underwater home with power and oxygen supply. :D- The base building leads to glitches due to weird placement and doesn't allow you to build really interesting and unique constructions - you are very limited by the segments that are available. - Some parts of the game (when you are leaving the starting area) are empty and are looking like placeholders, including minor graphical glitches. Summary:This game has potential, but there are (imo) far better survival games available on Steam for a similar price right now -  unless you REALLY love the underwater setting and the Apple-like design of your eqipment."Empyrion - Galactic Survival" has (imo) way more to offfer. You start under similar conditions, but in the end game you have a whole galaxy to explore. Also you are not limited to base building: You can also create your own land vessels and (capital) spaceships from scratch, without the design limitations that come with this game. Ah, and you also have to keep an eye on your O2 level - depending on which kind of planet you are at the moment. :D "The long dark": Just brutal survival in an unforgiving and icecold enviroment. No base buidling, but the fight for every calorie that your body needs is rewarding enough. "7 days to die" - A Zombie - Minecraft for adults, with RPG elements and splatter. _____________Explanations. in case you are interested in the details and  the points marked with an *:Bugs:I've placed my gathered stuff and equpiment in the "waterproof boxes" that should stay where they are, to store your stuff, 7 of them. For starters without a base this are the only means to store your stuff. All of these boxes have been empty upon my return, according to the forum that is a known bug right now and the boxes work more like a trashcan that will delete your stuff after a while - despite the tooltip ingame saying the complete opposite. I wasted a lot of game time due to this bug. Lack of motivation:I have no clue what I am supposed to do. If the game would be just about surviving its way too easy, compared to games like "7 days to die" or "The Long dark". In this two titles its clear after 5-10 minutes that surviving is going to be hard and that you need to find food, water, clothing asap. In Subnautica you just swim out and grab some fish, without any danger, and you are done. Enough food and water for the next few days. If the game should be about progressing, levelling up, gathering mats and crafting new stuff: I don't see any of this, anything that could motivate me to continue playing. The story sent me to the other rescue capsules and I went down to the deep bottom of the sea, and there have been random cubes (that looked like glitches or placeholders) lying around, that I had to scan (?) and that either give me A: Blueprints for stuff that I don't want and don't need to build or B: metal that is available in abundance anyway. In addition the bottom of the sea was looking empty and buggy to me - repeating textures and  graphical glitches (flickering).Good night everyone! <3

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've bought this game after seeing a couple people play it on the youtubes, decided to buy it on a sale, and by the Great Beard of Grouchy Odin, I've enjoyed every hour of playing this game (even when the stalker killed me through 15cm of steel), I can and will recommend this to anyone, but don't expect this to glitch free, (early access), the amount of swimming you can do, and the satisfaction you get after crafting so many things to make your life easier! DAMN. This game is stunning, I've played it for a decent amount of time (All hours on hardcore, which I would recommend to anyone since it makes you really not want to die.), but all in all it lacks content. Sure it is early access so we can expect more  to be added, but it seriously needs more creatures (There aren't that many. Don't let the sounds fool you.) The biomes seem to repeat themselves a lot too. In my opinion the content needs to be tripled for it to become a fully fledged game.  Small pros and cons list for the sake of it:Pros:- Beautiful game (with VR support)- Very atmospheric - Lots to explore- Surprisngly satisfying crafting system (imo) - Terra former gun (for making rock gentials. Get it!)- Supposedly will get better- Resources don't respawn! (YOU HAVE TO EXPLORE!!!)Cons (Mostly related to early access):- Needs more content (creatures, biomes, crafting)- Crafting needs better explanation (In regards to the Pro: Yes its fun, but lacks proper explanation)- Buggy as hell- Unstable- Its early access.Its a mastapiece. A buggy one, but a masta piece.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								i love this game and it is probably one of the best early access games i have ever played, and i know im gonna get lots of mixed reactions from this but i would very much love to see a multiplayer version in the future, i think that it can function well as a multiplayer game without any major adjustments to gameplay and story (some minor things like the base saying that someone has entered would be cool, things like that) but anyways on to the reviewTHIS IS MY OPINION SO IF YOU HAVE SOMETHING TO SAY YOU CAN SHOVE IT UP YOUR ***PROS:-the story (so far) is pretty cool and there are some cool little things that you can notice if you listen closely-the gameplay is very well done and varied, there is so much to do in this game once you get to a place where you arent starving to death, from exploring the depths of the (sometimes scary) ocean to building your underwater fortress i am never bored -the graphics for this game are astounding, especially for an early access game. so much detail goes into every little bit. just looking at the animal life even at the start of the game is incredible (at least to me)CONS:-there are many glitches (as to be expected with an early access game) specifically with the terraformer but im sure it will be straightened out in the future-many of the entities have weird hitboxes or seemingly no hitbox at all and this, as you can imagine is a big problem, it also may have been straightened out in the new update but i havent had time to check-long load times and, at least for me i dont know if anyone else has this problem, but corrupted saves happen pretty frequentlyPlease buy this game it is totaly worth $20        7.5/10Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: April 19
Early Access Review
								The art is wonderful. I've been playing this for awhile, and I have to admiit that gameplay has slowly improved, and that the game no longer crashes fifty times in four or five hours of play. That being said.... this is not a game for the goal oriented. The frustration induced by severe bugs at critical moments is (almost- it's been close) enough to make you throw your keyboard through your monitor. I have a total of 318 hours into this game. I've used the f8 (report bug or issue) function every time something made a game unplayable- and I've never yet received a response. I really wish the developers would wrap this up- I'm going to have to stop playing it at this point because the bugs are fatal. Once one crops up, you're done. That game and the time you've invested into it are gone, and you have to start from scratch. I had several advanced games that literally died in the water because there's no debug on load routine- and only one save per game so you can't just go back and lose an hour's play or so. If you worship Sisyphus, this is your game- because you'll be slogging uphill forever.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm not normally a huge fan of Survival games, though this game's ability to play in various "modes" helps a good deal towards letting me play it as I like.I'd say the two things it most has going for it- at least for someone like me is:A) You can build- a lot and creatively.B) It is ~immensely~ well done in the atmosphere department.  As I've remarked elsewhere in forum threads around this idea: even with damage turned off (I know I basically can't get hurt), standing on the edge of a potentially endless and unknown abyss is really, really forboding.  This game captures a nice blend of sandboxy-goodness and awe-inspiring environments.  You can relax and go all zen while you put things together and create your masterpiece, or you can sally forth into new 'worlds' to witness the beauty and the terror of it all.Highly reccomended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								As an avid Minecraft player, I had high hopes for this game.  And I was not disappointed.  Fully customizable seabases, several pilotable vehicles, loads of sealife, a satisfying amount of loot and crafting, and so much more!  I remember when minecraft was in early alpha and I have to say this game is much better rounded for being at roughly the same point.  The only MAJOR issues I have with this game so far is the finite loot system and a couple bugs, but the bugs at least will be fixed for sure in the future.  Regardless, Subnautica has promise to be on the same level of popularity as minecraft, while still maintaining its own unique play style and story.  P.S. having played almost every survival game out there, I can say that this is the best package I have seen for the aspiring Steve zissou in all of us.  So to the developers, good work and good luck; I'll be playing this gem just as much as minecraft or terraria.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								In a time when the phrase 'early access' is usually met with a cacophony of wails and groans, I was admittedly skepitcal about purchasing Subnautica. It also didn't help that I have mild Thalassophobia - a fear of deep bodies of water. Combining these things together you might expect me to have avoided this game like the plague; however, a chance stumbling upon of a video featuring this game by a Youtuber I sometimes watch(Video Sage) piqued my interest and I'm glad that it did.Having now clocked in a little over 90 hours in just two weeks, I can safely say that Subnautica is worth your time not only as an early access game, but also just in general. Unlike many games that fall into this category, Subnautica featured very few trips to it's wiki page to figure out what I should be doing and how to go about doing it. It's a self contained title which does a reasonable job of guiding new players into it's depths and arming them with the tools they need to explore and thrive.It helps that Subnautica is a truly beautiful game, which makes exploration of it's various distinct 'biomes' well worth your time. Each such biome (usually) contains a diversity of flora and fauna for you to observe and interact with. The lighting effects and ambiance which accompany each biome are also wonderful. From the deep, dark blue of the grand reef to the algae green of the kept forests, each biome truly looks unique and interesting.Of course what good is a bunch of pretty scenery without strange creatures to inhabit it? Subnautica won't disappoint in this regard either as each biome features many creatures both small and large. These creatures range from tiny and annoying to massive and peaceful. Some can be captured and eaten(or even be bred in large alien containment units). Others are merely there to add flavour and wonder to the environment... And some are there to make a meal out of you.It's up to the player to discover which is which, but thankfully you have the ability to construct large underwater 'seabases' to house all your belongings and act as a safe haven. These bases can be thoroughly customized with a variety of useful utilities or even just decorations. They can be built pretty much anywhere and at any depth, and help add a feeling of permanence to your game world.Ultimately, at it's heart, Subnautica is an exploration game though, moreso even than a survival or building game. Swimming out into it's waers and discovering new biomes, creatures, and secrets beneath the waves is what it's best at. Indeed, much of the games progression system and the various base parts, tools, and items that the player can craft require you to venture into the world and find scannable 'fragements' to unlock their use, thus rewarding the players exploration wit tangible benefits.All of the things I have mentioned here are, on their own, offer plenty of the reasons to purchase Subnautica. It's beautiful, deep, and has much to offer. However at the almost insane asking price of 20$ USD, Subnautica isn't just a value. It's a steal. I really don't think anyone would regret their purchase.Pros:- Beauitiful world to explore and catalogue.- Many interesting creatures to eat or be eaten by.- Lots of fun and interesting tools to craft and play with.- Powerful, craftable vehicles to explore and exploit the world with.- Interesting(though WIP) storyline that gently nudges the player forward.- Very near feature completion, this is the best time to get into early access.Cons:- Not all biomes or story elements are complete.- Game does suffer from some bugs, though few and far between generally.- Early access, game balance and features in a state of flux.- Wiki reading is usually not needed, but occasionally may be.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								A great early access game. The environments are rich in all types of ocean life and it has a mystery and horror-behind-charm that leave me wanting to play more. However frequent crashes upon loading new areas have left it almost unplayable on my only and longest running save. I am completely sure that I meet the minimum requirements, in fact my build exceeds them, though almost every time, upon moving a few meters past my initial starting point, it crashes without fail. To reiterate, this is surely one of the best, if not the best, underwater-survival-horror- (because ya' know, crabsquids and leviathans, need I say more.) building-exploration-games you can possibly find on any game selling website or application, but remember where your money is going. Probably some hard-working super creative devs that simply haven't had time to optimize their masterwork, hence, early access is an exceedingly correct title. Please use your money wisely, if you don't want to experience a few crashes and bugs along the road, don't buy. If you are willing to tolerate them, buy. Buy because it's an amazing visual experience not tailored to those who fear the ocean, or those who fear the risk of early access.

content:
Posted: March 19
Early Access Review
								I both love and hate this game. I love it because it's so immersive, the detail is amazing, and the storyline, although not quite complete yet, is awesome. I hate it because I played it for a long while yesterday and that god-forsaken leviathan showed up in my nightmares. I ran into it twice yesterday, once when I was cruising in my seamoth, and it appeared out of nowhere right in front of me. I thought it didn't see me, so i high tailed it in the other direction thinking I could outrun it. Spoiler alert: I didn't. It showed up front-and-center and proceeded to eat my seamoth. I did the only thing I could do. I exited the seamoth, and swam as fast as I could. I looked back and saw the leviathan shake my poor seamoth in it's jaws and I heard the explosion. Thankfully I got away, somehow.I was passing by the area later, ever watchful, and I saw a stalker a few yards away near the surface by the aurora. I looked away from it and my entire screen was filled with red and white as the leviathan bit into the stalker from below and flew through the air like some kind of special on the discovery channel. I sped off and didn't look back. RIP stalker, you saved me and my seamoth.This game is amazing, and terrifying. I'm already afraid of deep water and this game has not helped me overcome that fear. I love open world games like this and it's one of the best games like it I've ever played, and it's not even complete yet. Keep up the great work, I can't wait till it's complete.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great graphics and super-simple interface.  If you like to scrounge, build, and occasionally fight - yes!  It reminds me of the first time I saw a video of Cousteau on his Calypso.   It seems a little lonely without a cooperative mode, but that didn't stop anyone from enjoying other single player adventures.  Things I like - visually stunning, progressive difficulty, discovery.Things I didn't like - learn as you go, no map or direction finding (except pod point beacon), twitchy fish and short range scanner make scanning a chore. Things I would change or add - character customization (including sounds) for gender, color, etc.; a way to seek rare materials (like a long-range scanner), and a quest list of things to do (remind me to find magnesium for my welder).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
A one of a kind aquatic exploration game.Subnautica is one of the games currently caught up in the survival genre craze. It stands out among the others by having an underwater setting.The game mainly focuses on crafting anything from a knife to a fully fledged submarine, and exploration. Lots and lots of exploration.You're pushed to explore by the aforementioned crafting system, which requires obscene amounts of materials that you have to gather from various biomes. Due to the fact that the game has no respawnable resources at the time of this review (Aug 8, 2015), you'll eventually find that the area you start in becomes barren of resources and you're forced to either relocate your base or go on scavaging expeditions.The crafting and building system really comes into play once you decide to build an underwater base. With the recent Habitat update you're able to craft vast interconnected buildings with everything from a dock for your small submarine (the Seamoth) to an observation lounge and an aquarium. Of course with all these buildings comes an expanded hunt for materials which may bring you to unexpected biomes far from your comfort zone.   ---The survival part of this survival game is a bit lackluster at the moment; Not a whole lot of creatures will attempt to kill you, even fewer will succeed. The only real threat from a creature in the game right now comes from the Reaper Leviathan, who roam the crashed spaceship "Aurora", but you'll always run the risk of suffocating underwater - and that's where you'll spend most of your time. There's also a system for food and water intake, however it isn't very difficult to manage.The crafting part of the game is intriguing. You'll have to craft rudimentary tools and high level tech to advance in the game. Most crafts are semi-optional (depending on how you play and where you go), but some gear has to be crafted to stay ahead of the game and not get stuck singing shanties on a lifeboat.The building part of the game is exceptional. A large variety of buildings to choose from, the freedom of choosing any location in the game to start building, and an easy-to-use building system all contribute to an amazing underwater building game.The exploration part of the game is lovely. The graphical details of the glowing flora and fauna in an underwater environment can't be described in any other words. It is lovely.---The only major drawback of this game is that, if you don't find yourself incredibly interested in exploring every inch of the map, it doesn't really have any viable content once you've built everything you can build. But, hey, this is an Early Access game - it's still being developed and new content is added frequently!If you like survival games, exploring, the deep blue sea, and building, you should definitely get this game now and help the developers make it the perfect underwater survival game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Amazing game, easily worth more than the sticker price. A few glaring bugs, but mostly cosmetic. Nothing game-breaking so far.The graphics are jaw-droppingly gorgeous. The biomes and sealife that abound are beautiful, colorful, and varied. The planet really feels like a living, breathing world, and contains plenty of surprises as you progress into more dangerous areas. I like that the game includes some flavor text for the flora and fauna, which adds some fun to exploration beyond just chasing the next upgrade.The controls are great. I like that base-building is a bit easier compared to most survival games - in others it tends to feel like a chore to me. Advanced upgrades are expensive, but the basic elements like rooms and corridors are cheap, so you don't have to spend hours finding resources just to customize your base.The game is more about exploration than survival, as your advanced technology and the abundant sealife make it easy to subsist indefinitely in the starting area. The real challenge comes from venturing outward. Exploring wreckage, caverns, new biomes, where large predators and dangerous depths are a constant threat.My one major criticism about the game is acquiring new technology, which has to be done by exploring the scattered wreckage from your ship and scanning various items to get more advanced blueprints. In principle I think this mechanic is fine, but a lot of the fragments are rare, only found in a few select locations. I resorted to looking online, which took a lot of the fun out of it, but it was better than searching aimlessly for hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								When you buy this game, you have to be aware that it is still Early Access. It's not completed. It's still rather buggy. However, to be part of this game as it is being built, to give suggestions and feedback that could have real implications on the final game, is an experience like no other.Pros:- The absolute creativity that went into everything in this game. The different biomes that were constructed, the animals, the utterly unique feeling to every inch of the planet the developers created. It's amazing.- The ability to build whatever you want, wherever you want. Within reason. You want a simple base at or above sea level? No problem! Want a massive, sprawling mansion over 1000M below sea level? Sure thing, just make sure you know how to power it.- One of my absolute favorite things, though others might not agree, is that there are actual consequences to not thinking ahead. Decide to build a bioreactor to power your base in the kelp forest? Then you cut down that kelp forest to fuel it, only to realize later that there's no forest anymore? Then you realize you should have grown your own, instead of cutting down every last creepvine in a 1km radius.Cons:- Stuttering. My computer is above the recommended specs, but I still get a lot of macro and micro stuttering on the medium graphic setting. The High setting is virtually unplayable for me. If you don't care about how the game looks, then play on minimum.- Some predators are overly aggressive. Admittedly, this is likely on purpose as large predators will often attack anything that enters their territory - familiar or not. But I can't tell you how many times I've had my little Sea Moth sub pushed below pressure limits and nearly destroyed while I was exploring a wreck, just because some predators kept attacking it while I wasn't there.- Perhaps the worst downside for me, personally, is that the world is too small. There is a ton of variety, the world is built up and down as well as side to side. But once you get familiar with every corner (which does, admittedly, take a very long time) it just feels so dang /small/. Once you start building the larger vehicles, and getting some speed on your side, it takes no time at all to get form point A to point B. Even if doubling the size of the landscape pushed back the official release date by a year, I'd prefer that.Regardless of whatever cons I've seen and experienced in my game, it won't be the same for everyone. Do I heartily recommend this game to anyone who likes exploring and discovering new things? Yes. Would I recommend this game to someone who doesn't like survival games? Yes, because you don't have to do the survival mode. This is perhaps a game I've had the most fun with since Fallout 4, and before that Skyrim. I love Bethesda games for their freedom, and their explorability. Subnautica hits both of those points right on the nose.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic. It is not advertised as such but it does become a bit of a survival horror game, but I am completely okay with that. Deep sea exploration can be genuinely scary and this is done on a hidden, lonely, alien world, with only dangerous sea creatures and the wreckage of your ship to keep you company.A positive addition to this game which would make it perfect would be co-op support and balance. Subnautica would be so much better if you could play it with at least 1 co-op partner. Perhaps this is in development already but I am not sure, i'm too busy looking for Moon Pools to care. :UThe one game mechanic that I have any gripes about, which are all minor, is the objectives system. You get an objective by answering the radio for incoming distress calls, which will give you coordinates to the escape pod sending them. The problem is that these distress signals are equippable, and you can have 2 radio items equipped, one of which can be your compass. When you're done with the objective, you can unequip the distress signal coordinates and then put them in storage or discard them. This system could be significantly improved if you can just equip and unequip distress signals within its own interface, or within a new tab in your PDA. The system can then be improved by adding information on the signals themselves, such as the date you acquired them, and what research you found nearby, or what PDA's you found nearby.There is also a known Framerate problem in this game which you can correct by deleting a specific file from your Subnautica folder [There are steam community discussions and forum posts about this]. No one besides the dev knows this files purpose, but deleting it corrects a lot of the critical drops in framerates which occur at total random and have no other known solutions or causes, and deleting this file doesn't seem to cause any real big problematic side effects.

								Great graphics and super-simple interface.  If you like to scrounge, build, and occasionally fight - yes!  It reminds me of the first time I saw a video of Cousteau on his Calypso.   It seems a little lonely without a cooperative mode, but that didn't stop anyone from enjoying other single player adventures.  Things I like - visually stunning, progressive difficulty, discovery.Things I didn't like - learn as you go, no map or direction finding (except pod point beacon), twitchy fish and short range scanner make scanning a chore. Things I would change or add - character customization (including sounds) for gender, color, etc.; a way to seek rare materials (like a long-range scanner), and a quest list of things to do (remind me to find magnesium for my welder).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
Early access review of the March 15 2015 build (post-sea bases, pre-crash site).In BriefSomewhere between Planet Explorers, Endless Ocean and Stranded Deep, Subnautica is the alien world exploration game you dreamed about as a kid.Most valuable resource: the slick, gorgeous aqua-sci-fi graphics.Of interest to: people who want their survival games to be more about exploration than hostiles, and who fantasise about alien planets.The premise of Subnautica is that you are the lone survivor of a crashed terraforming vessel on a water world and now have to use the meagre technology on your life pod, salvage from the downed Aurora, and whatever natural resources you can scavenge from the sea floor of this planet to survive and, potentially, begin the terraforming process.  Exciting stuff, yeah?So how much of this is in place at this stage?  Enough to give you a good few days' entertainment.  You can craft the basic gear you need, construct a basic submersible and, with patience, a submarine, or build an aquatic base.  You can explore the shallows where you start easily enough with just a single diving tank, but the other equipment, and the vehicles, become a must for deeper or wider wandering.The crafting process is simple at this stage, with only a few raw materials and very little required to make most things in a one- or two-step process of refinement and construction.  Resource gathering is basically swimming around and exploring your immediate environment, which is fun in itself and the real point of the game, so the process is satisfying.  The process for building underwater is handled very smoothly.There are only a few species of marine life at this stage.  A couple are hostile, but they have different behaviours when aggressive which keeps things interesting.  The rest are food, and swimming around catching them is enjoyable.  Some fish are solitary, some swim in schools, and their AI makes them seem quite plausible and unique, which is great for immersion.  When this game has whole ecosystems it will be incredible.  There is some slight evolutionary similarity between some of the fauna and flora - not to the same level as Planet Explorers but some - which is encouraging, although some fish are quite cartoony, so I hope they go for more realistic species design in the future.The biomes are interesting, especially the deep places like the volcanic vents and the jellyfish mushroom cave thing.  You definitely want to head SW at some point to check out the island supported on the back of the giant floaters - although currently it is a purely aesthetic place, when you've spent hours floating around in the water it feels so damn good to be walking around on land, surrounded by trees, however briefly.  My only complaint is that most biomes outside the shallow sea starting area severely lack resources, meaning they are pretty to visit but ultimately there is no reason to take up residence there.  This is almost certainly an early access thing.In fact the game sort of peters out once you have a sub, have gone for a quick circle of the biomes, built your basic sea base and have got a handle on food and water (which is really not an onerous task).  The content there is right now is great fun, but once it's done, there's kinda no point continuing.  New content is frequent enough to have you coming back every month or so to check it out, but it's still quite early days in terms of the play to be had in this game.The graphics have to be mentioned.  Although some (such as the Seamoth interior displays) are a little placeholdery, the graphics in this game are very polished.  The Aurora herself is the most stunning, but even the water textures when you're swimming are really on-the-money, and the appearance of sea base tubes and submersibles is very aqua-future.  The whole thing is very slick.  I especially like that you have a shadow and feet, and that when you swim backwards you can see your feet sticking out in front of you just as you would when swimming.  It's a little thing, but it's a little thing most survival games, especially those in early access, skip - the floating object shadows in Stranded Deep are really off-putting.The always-important question for all early access games is: how's the development?  These guys are up there with 7 Days as a model for early access development.  They have a public progress tracker showing what features are being worked on; they communicate frequently through the varioous channels they have; updates to the game are as frequent as can be expected, and major features seem to be pretty stable on release.  The game overall runs surprisingly well for one with constant physics objects and very pretty graphics, rarely experiencing frame rate issues on the recommended settings.  It does crash with no warning every so often, so save early and save often, but it's not so frequent an issue (for me, anyway) that it presents an annoyance.If you feel the price tag of $20 is a bit steep for the amount of game you get here right now, hold off until more of the core features are in place.  If you know you're going to be buying this eventually anyway, dive in now (ha!) and explore an alien ocean.  If development continues at this rate, by the end of this year there should be a very solid survival-exploration game to be had here.

This system could be significantly improved if you can just equip and unequip distress signals within its own interface, or within a new tab in your PDA. The system can then be improved by adding information on the signals themselves, such as the date you acquired them, and what research you found nearby, or what PDA's you found nearby.There is also a known Framerate problem in this game which you can correct by deleting a specific file from your Subnautica folder [There are steam community discussions and forum posts about this]. No one besides the dev knows this files purpose, but deleting it corrects a lot of the critical drops in framerates which occur at total random and have no other known solutions or causes, and deleting this file doesn't seem to cause any real big problematic side effects.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Subnautica is one of my all-time favorite games. Ever since I was young I've loved marine biology. I can tell you the state fish of Hawaii in their native tongue (humu-humu-nuku-nuku-apuah) and got my PADI and SSI scuba licenses before I could drive a car. I know, and expect, quite a bit when it comes to anything fish and ocean related and subnautica takes the cake for me. I don't quiet know what it is about Subnautica that makes me feel the way I do, it just does such a good job of replicating the emotions I feel when I dive myself. Of course, you're on an alien planet with alien creatures, but it still feels so... real in a way. You are awestruck by the great blue expanses, curious to explore every expertly crafted cavern and crevace, fearful of the unknown, yet driven enough to search anyway. You can swim alongside goliaths or scoot your sub along the reefs before delving into the dark and mysterious depths. These are the emotions you SHOULD feel when you're exploring an Ocean, and Subnautica does an amazing job of making the player feel immersed in their game.Of course, in order to convey these emotions, the game has to look good. The game features a large variety of bioluminessent and colourful life, not something you'd find in any ocean on earth, but necesary to keep the game looking and feeling alien, especially at night and in the darker depths. Every biome has been crafted to feel unique and every species in them has a purpose. If you find large schools of low-on-the-food-chain fish, you can expect that a preditor of that species is going to be nearby. The only problem with the game's graphics that exists thusfar is that the rendering can get a little messy in louder more clustered parts of the ocean, resulting in large formations popping into view, but this seems to be improving with everypatch.I can't say enough good things about subnatuica. To try and describe what it FEELS like to play this game would be impossible, it's something you have to try for yourself to truely understand, and if you get the chance to buy this game, I would absolutly jump on it. Especially if you are looking for a fun, exploration-driven survival game.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been playing this game in short bursts (because I suffer from thalassaphobia, an intense and persistent fear of the sea or similarly deep bodies of water) for a total of 14 hours. The devs are constantly releasing updates, and they're not just minor bugfixes, they actually add a lot of new stuff the game everytime. This game is terrifying and beautiful. If you like exploration, then this game is definitely worth a shot. Just remember to keep your ears open when you go near the crashed ship. You'll find out why. Night time is absolutely stunning in the game because just about everything is bioluminescant. The game isn't procedurally generated, which means each corner of this alien world is unique, beautiful, and painstakingly handcrafted. If you're looking for something to help you get over your fear of the ocean, this game won't help. It will just scare you and make you feel like a big blubbering baby, but it's a humbling experience to say the least. If you love your inner explorer, definitely try this amazing gem.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								This game is the foundation for a masterpiece. I'm not sure if I've ever enjoyed any other game this much. While being strictly science fiction, it still manages to hold some attributes that are analogous to some things in the real world. Creatures, like a stalker for example, are said to have developed streamlined bodies to be able to move fast and chase down prey. That is something you would expect from a moderate size sea dwelling predator living in our ocean. Of course some creatures are a fantasy by our standards, but they try their best to at least look alrightThe playability is pretty in depth, as opposed to the simplistic look you would see from the surface, pun intended. You can alter the way you explore the ocean you're in instead of just wandering around the same way every time. It's all about a balance of speed, thoroughness, and safety. Managing resources? Maybe not everyone's cup of tea, but I personally like it. I feel like it gives me more excuses to look around while going to any given destinationHowever there are some concerns. The game is still early in development so this is likely to change in the future, but as of when this is being typed, the way the game data is packaged is inefficient. As you play the game, collecting resources and everything, the game starts to lose stability until becoming unplayable. This is a major issue for those who invest lots of effort into a single save. On top of that, some of the features that have been in the game for some time aren't working as intended. The most notable is the torpedo arm for the Prawn suit. Very rarely will it actually fire a torpedo instead of consuming the torpedo but not actually firing it. Other things I could rant about here would just be little nitpicks thoughThe best part about Subnautica for me personally is the horror game aspect of it. It doesn't try to be a horror game at all, yet it's genuinely one of, if not the scariest game I've ever played. It achieves this by playing on our natural survival instincts, and using the ambience itself to set a creepy atmosphere. Everything you could classify as a typical jumpscare is us just overreacting to something harmless. But that isn't horror. It's cheap humor. This is where Subnautica really gets it right. It doesn't do anything cheap. There's nothing down there actively waiting to scare you. It's all driven by our fear of the unknown, and fear for our survival. You either have to build a means of transport to go down, or man up a lot. Either way, horror games need to look to Subnautica for inspiration. They don't seem like they're a strong genre anymore

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Since I know most don't like long paragraphs to read or vast amounts of info, I will keep the style of this review in short bullet point like chunks.PROS:Large Open World - Game is vast, enjoyable, gorgeous and very addicting. From the moment you begin on your very first time playing it, you starting wondering "Wow! What else can I do?" so you keep exploring.Chllenging level of play -  When on survival, it isn't easy to manage your hunger and thirst to begin with. You soon learn what's best to eat and the easiest way to get water. As you progress, it is made easier with discovories.Gorgeous Soundtrack - The game has music that is just beautiful. Going from one section where it's shallow reefs and you hear a catchy, bouncy tune that you nod you head along to, to finding the blood kelp forest where a gorgeous, soothing quire track kicks in and you just think "Oh my god, it's so beautiful!" ;w;Clever A.I. - I won't sing to the high heavens about the A.I in the game as it isn't on par with some games out there, but it is damn impressive for what is there. All the creatures have their preferred habitat and ways of interacting with the world and you as the player. Some are hostile, some are peaceful. And some are terrifyingly clever like the Warper who creates portals and can use them to bring larger, nasty creatures into the area to attack you! D:Suspenseful Atmosphere - The game is not exactly the comfort playing kind of game it may seem on the surface, (pardon the pun. XD) All of the screenshots show truth (unlike No Man's Lie, :P), but they're not going to be found with ease. You will have to travel through vast, open oceans, which could hold anything in them. And when there's nothing but darkness around you and  you hear a deep, booming roar from something, you will need to change your underwear. :3Deep Lore - While the game isn't even complete, it already has quite an exansive lore. The use of the in game scanner to study the flora and fauna and finding data terminals and PDA pads to find out more information which all gets added into the in game encyclopedia blows my mind and I can't imagine what it's going to be like when the game IS finished.Fascinating Creatures - A few of the creatures are amusing and not exactly impressive, like the Garry fish named so after a particular SpongeBob Squarepants character who's appearance it's based upon. :P But then you get to some other creatures, like the beautful Reef Backs, that are like giant, living islands, basically the games whales. And then you have Ampeels, giant, electric eel like creatures, Sand Sharks... their name gives it away. And yes, they ACTUALLY swim through sand with their dorsal fin sticking up and out of it. And then... You have the Laviathans... For those of you who may not know the word Laviathan, I'll put it this way... It means big. And in this game, that's unfriendly. O_OImpressive Base Building - I know there are many ghames out there already that give base building, all of which offer their own style from Minecraft to Fallout 4. Some have said this game, Subnautica, is Minecraft underwater. Do NOT listen to them. This game overshadows Minecraft since it's actually not just some cash cow of a game. (No offence to Minecraft, it started off an amazing game, but has become a cashcow.) The base construction is clever and unique, and having to find other parts of the base to scan before you build it gives you a reason to explore the world. The way vehicles can interact with the base is also amazing!Clever Vehicles - From the basic Seaglide that carries you along at a smooth, basic pace to the Seamoth, a small, mini submarine like vehicle that can get you further, and then the cylops. A massive submarine that is just the bomb! The fact you can customize these vehicles with colors and names is also amazing! Oh, and you also get a P.R.A.W.N Suit. Which is basically an underwater mech suit which you can customize as well, including equipping different types of arms. Need I say more? I named mine Iron Man and made it red and gold. ^W^Different Play Modes - For those of you who may not be into the survival part of it and just wish to explore the world without having to worry about food, water, dying and having to find materials to build with, you can play in a creative mode that lets you have free will with no limits while also disabling the story.CONS:Bugs - This is really the only con that there is in the game. The game is BUGGED. And I don't mean lightly. Every update the devs improve and I give a round of applause to them since they do an amazing job. For the game it is, Subnautica can't be easy to maintain with an indie team, but bugs are there. Some are minor, like shoals of fish swimming through your base walls and your custom PRAWN suit color changing your entire characters skin to it as well, to a large one where after several hours of gameplay the game will start CTD'ing. (Crashing To Desktop) Some players have discovered a temporary fix to this issue so it's no longer a game breaking bug, but I am more than sure that the devs are aware of all issues and working to fix them.Other things to note are that not everything is polished yet. Some placeholders are missing, animations could do with some work, etc. All things that the developers are more than likely working on.The only thing to say is just be prepared. This is a warning the game is buggy and not complete, but not unplayable. The devs also are working on the end game content as well, so there's that to look forward to.Overal, would I suggest you buy this game? Hell yes! If you're into survival, open world exploring and discovering stuff and buidling stuff, this is the game for you! And if it's on sale then, oh god, YES you should buy it! But I'd say get it at full price to help the devs as much as you can.This game is AWESOME! It's scary as all balls, but awesome! 9.0/10. (Would be 10/10 for me if it wasn't as buggy, optimized and polished.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								One of the BEST RIFT EXPERIENCES CURRENTLY AVAILBLE.  If you own a Rift, you have to get this game.  Think Discovering Space but Underwater and with a heck of a lot more content, even at this stage.  If you are like me and have an Oculus that you want to get the most out of, you have probably searched for "VR" or used the steam "VR Support" tag to find games.  That's how I found this.  This was the most immersive experience I had to date.  Use the F2 key, lean forward in the rift, hit F2 and then lean back ...in the Seamoth that you can build or cheat code (hit enter, type "item seamoth" then hit enter again.) ...it has an obvious interface.    There I was, about 1.5 miles down.  It is dark and I am hearing some strange roaring sound.  I am looking behind me (literally, remember I'm in the Oculus Rift so I physically turn around to see anything...nope, it's just my little Submersible.  What was that noise?  Deeper I go still... You know how you can tell a game is fun?  When there was literally nothing at the bottom to find and I STILL had fun looking for it.  The ambience is top notch for an early alpha.  The developers are obviously working at the surface and building their way down.  But these guys made Natural Selection 2, which I also own, and I know they have what it takes to see this through.  FYI I am running this on a 2013 Sager dual GPU laptop.  Runs great on Recommended settings.  You CAN get this to work on Extend mode (Direct always crashes for me)...check the community guide on Oculus, I put some comments there on how to get it to work.  Right now it is very early.  And I have played and have had lots of fun in early games, even the ones that didn't amount to anything.  (like Starforge, such a shame really)...  But I can tell this game is going to get finished.  The parts that are in are, to me, VERY polished.  This is one of those developers that makes takes time to make high quality items.  Note As of date of this review, I still highly recommend, but you cannot craft in the game when using Oculus.  (literally, even if you turn off rift and see the double vision on your monitor, it is an interface problem, you cannot actually click on the crafting menu).  Devs are on it I'm told.  Disregard playing time, it's a lot more....

content:

Early Access Review
								Subnautica is basically everything I've dreamed of with regards to an underwater-exploration-adventure+scifi game.  In other words, it's amazing!  The content already employed is very impressive and enjoyable.  The mechanics of the game also work very well which is something that I more than appreciate -- everything from crafting to maneuvering.  And, while this may seem like a small and unrelated thing, it is still something to note that is indicative of good developers.  The fact that you can report bugs and give feedback through a simple push of a button in-game is a very positive thing, for everyone involved!  Makes it much easier for the player to report things and makes it easier for the developer to find out about things.  Back to the game...seriously, it's extremely fun.  If you've ever wanted to explore a vast underwater ecosystem full of both wonder and horror, this should be next on your list.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a person who never sets foot in the ocean ever due to fear of open water and the ocean in general, it seems quite a surprise even to me that I find this game so accessible. Don't get me wrong I am fascinated and love the allure and beauty of the underwater world but in reality I am happy to appreciate it from a very far distance. I have a dread for sharks and it is the reason I cannot play any similar water based games. However, as I mentioned this game's design and approach is genius with its method of introducing you to its world through the amazing aesthetic of the initial shallows without any threat whatsoever in the beginning parts of the game. The genius part for me are the more threatening aspects of the games where the approach is one where the creatures are designed in a more abstract style rather than mimicking real world forms so much, and this I feel helps, me at least, tolerate it with my inherent fear of real world ocean threats. That all being said, I love this game. Everything about it is rich in quality, and design mastery, all balanced so well with the game play mechanics, at least so far what is available. I have only played a few hours and still have quite a bit to do before I can get the Cyclops and explore the real depths of this world. I am looking forward to the progress of this game as it can only get better. But so far there is enough in the game for me to just enjoy swimming in this amazing ocean of beauty, I can’t get enough of it. It is probably the closest I will ever get to the real thing and I am grateful to the developers for that. Well done Unknown Worlds!

content:
Posted: March 7
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								This game isn't perfect- but d@mned close. Right from the start, it shows that it's considerate of it's players, by giving you fully customizable controls, not the hardwired nonsense some game devs seem to always sneak in. And it lets you choose between a variety of difficulties, based on playstyle. Survival mode isn't brutal, but it's definitely challenging. Creative mode gives you fantastic resources to begin with and lets you explore both the game world, and the game's mechanics, so it's a great way to get the knack of the controls and systems. The world offers up beauty, whimsy, and the gut-wrenching primal fear you only get from swimming over what seems a bottomless abyss. I can't wait to see this game when it's fully polished.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game speaks to my deeply rooted phobia of deep water environments.  I HATE deep water.  I'm not afraid of the water itself, but of WHAT is lurking beneath, above, and behind me in the water.  Too many close encounters with marine life in my real life experiences I suppose.  That said, this game had me terror stricken from the beginning, and my heart never ceases to want to explode from my chest as I play this game.  It scares the crap out of me!  So in a nutshell, I absolutely love this freekin game!  It's one of the best survival/horror games I have ever played.  If you think it's boring, then try diving down 100+ meters in murky low visibility water with just an air bag to get you back to the surface, before something big and hungry grabs your backside for a quick snack.  I scare myself just thinking about it (phobia kicking in).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's been a long time since I was genuinely surprised and awed by a game, and Subnautica does just that. It's full of creepy surprises in its vast and beautiful ocean, like large eels jumping out of glowing jelly mushrooms to grab you with their pincers. There have been many times where I just sat back and stared in amazement, like when I built the Cyclops submarine, which is absolutly massive, or encountered some of the huge underwater wildlife. Even some moments inspire a little bit of panic, such as when you're franticly fleeing the massive Reaper that lurks deep underwater near your wrecked ship.Overall, this is totally worth the twenty dollar price tag, and the best part this is still early access, so there will be much more!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'd been looking for a good, immersive underwater game (tried others: FarSky, Depth Hunter 2, Depth), but nothing compares to the quality I found in Subnautica. It's truly hard to believe the game is in Early Access (with regular monthly updates).The science-fiction setting makes it all the more interesting to me, because it opens the doors for more freedom of creativity, with amazing-looking alien fauna and flora to discover while exploring the beautiful underwater landscape. The feeling of being underwater pervades throughout the game, with realistic sound effects and colorful visuals.The elements of exploration and survival are strong, with a taste of mystery, as you're trying to find out what happened to the crew of your crashed spaceship, with parts of the ship and lifepods spread out all over on the sea bed.Gameplay options allow you to choose the degree of survival difficulty, including a creative mode if you want to build stuff without having to worry about dying or unlocking technologies.Bottomline, I absolutely love this game, and I'm looking forward to it being finished.
